H0.text: Earth is farthest away from the Sun on the winter solstice, the date that falls on December 21 or 22 depending on the year, when Massachusetts experiences the least amount of daylight.

H1.text: Earth's rotational speed on its axis is greatest on the winter solstice (December 21 or 22, depending on the year), which explains why that time of year has the least amount of daylight in Massachusetts.

H2.text: Earth is traveling around the Sun with the greatest speed on the winter solstice (December 21 or 22, depending on the year), which explains why that time of year has the least amount of daylight in Massachusetts.

H3.text: Earth's Northern Hemisphere is tilted away from the Sun on the winter solstice, which is why the winter solstice—occurring on December 21 or 22 depending on the year—has the least amount of daylight in Massachusetts.

A4.text: The winter solstice, or hibernal solstice, occurs when either of Earth's poles reaches its maximum tilt away from the Sun.

A5.text: For that hemisphere, the winter solstice is the day with the shortest period of daylight and longest night of the year.
